Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), which I shall introduce shortly, comprise the additional estimates for 1988-89.

In these Bills, Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made for 1988-89 under Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act.
These additional appropriations are required to meet commitments that have been approved by the Government since the Budget as well as requirements of an on-going nature.

The principal factors underlying the requirements include certain unavoidable cost and price increases and other parameter changes since the Budget was prepared. Although the Budget figuring contained allowances for prospective wage and salary increases, those amounts were not then appropriated, and funds are now required to meet the impact of the national wage case decision.

Of the additional appropriations in the three additional Estimates Bills totalling $683.9m, $609.9m is sought in Appropriation Bill No. 3, $68.4m in Appropriation Bill No. 4 and $5.7m in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill No. 2.

These amounts are offset in part by savings in the appropriations made by Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act, 1988-89 reflecting the Government's continued determination to improve the efficiency of ongoing programs. These savings, amounting to $425.7m are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document, ``Statement of savings expected in annual appropriations'', which has been distributed to senators. In addition, a clause which has the effect of reducing an appropriation for the Defence Service Homes Corporation made by Appropriation Act (No. 2) by $40.5m is included in Appropriation Bill (No. 4).

After allowance for this reduction and prospective savings, the appropriations now sought represent a net increase of $217.8m in expenditures financed from annual appropriations. As a proportion of total estimated outlays-encompassing both annual and standing appropriations-this increase amounts to 0.3 per cent.

I now outline some of the main areas in respect of which the Government has found it necessary to seek additional provisions in the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89 to meet expenditure for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

One hundred and thirty million dollars is included to cover the costs of the national wage case. Other significant amounts provided in the running costs appropriations include $35m for early retirement; these funds have been `borrowed' by departments and agencies under the negative carryover provisions of the running costs appropriations.

With regard to the defence portfolio, gross additional estimates of $241.2m are sought in Appropriation Bill (No. 3), significantly offset by savings of $145.5m giving a net increase of $95.7m in Consolidated Revenue Fund expenditures.

The gross figures included $122m for running costs, reflecting the impact of the national wage case and other awards on civilian and defence personnel salaries and allowances; a provision of $14.9m for redundancies; and $20.6m increase in the provision for fringe benefits tax. Other costs of $47.7m not provided for at Budget time are associated with the establishment of Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd. The additional funding of $9.1m provided for defence housing, largely reflects increases in market rents to be paid by defence to the Defence Housing Authority. In summary, and taking account of all transactions contributing to the defence function, total defence outlays are estimated to increase by $79.6m.

Appropriation Bill (No. 3) also provides $50m for the Australian Trade Commission to meet eligible grants under the Export market development grant scheme. The additional funds are estimated to be sufficient to enable settlement of all grants that are expected to be processed and hence payable by 30 June.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Treasurer referred last night to `the past tightening of fiscal and monetary policy'; those words appear in the statement. Particularly in regard to monetary policy, does this mean that there will be no further tightening in the foreseeable future? Is the Government saying that there will be no further interest rate increases?
—The Government, I think it is fair to say, began tightening monetary policy in about July last year.
—April.

—In April, I thank the honourable senator. I want to get it right. There is nothing that can be construed from the Treasurer's statement, when he refers to past tightening of fiscal and monetary policy, that there will be no further tightening of either of those policies if it becomes necessary. But the Government does not believe that it will become necessary because it is already considered that demand in the Australian economy is slowing. It has been made clear all along that each of those policy weapons will be used if we have to achieve a slower rate of growth than is now anticipated.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, concerns two notable omissions from last night's economic statement, namely, the failure to address interest rates as they relate to home loans and the failure to move to encourage savings. In view of the Treasurer's concern, when in his expenditure cutting mode, about the level of savings in Australia, the Economic Planning Advisory Council's observation in December last year that `without a significant improvement in the incentive for savers framework private saving is unlikely to make a major contribution to the further adjustment in domestic savings that is needed', and Senator Button's own statement as reported recently, `I said the other day that I think we ought to do something about savings. I think we've got to look at that and I think we probably will', why has the Government taken no action to encourage savings, for example, by exempting from tax some of the interest people earn, or to protect home buyers from the likelihood of further interest rate rises, for example by introducing some form of tax deductability for mortgage repayments?

—I did say something about the desirability of doing something about the savings ratio, I think about three months ago. That was before the publication of the national accounts figures which showed an improvement in the savings ratio, the household savings ratio increasing by 9.9 per cent and reaching its highest level since the December quarter of 1981. Those figures were published last week or the week before. That is encouraging. In regard to the first part of the question, which relates to interest rates, Senator Haines seems to have been labouring under a misunderstanding for the last few months about the purpose of monetary policy in reducing the levels of demand. One area where there has been excessive demand, of course, has been the housing sector. We will not be embarking on any funny little scheme which might emanate from the Democrats or somewhere else to distort that process.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that savings are now sufficiently high that there is no need for people to curb their expenditure, as the Treasurer has been demanding of them in recent months? Further, is the Minister therefore also going to recommend that the recently reintroduced negative gearing capacity for investors in the housing market be removed to further curb housing expenditure?

—The answer to the second part of the question is no. I cannot answer the first part of the question as to whether savings in the community are sufficiently high. I do not know what the optimum level of savings in the community is for the most desirable results. What I did say was that there has been a considerable improvement in the household savings ratio, according to the national accounts figures.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Is the Minister aware that an outbreak of foot and mouth disease could cost Australian agricultural production in the order of $1.6 billion per year, with an estimated cost of eradication of around $4 billion per year for some years? What sort of mechanism has the Government got in place to allay fears about the possible introduction of these diseases? What is the Government doing to ensure that first time arriving passengers and, indeed, returning passengers are made aware of the importance of quarantine controls?

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —Yes, the Government is concerned that Australia, as a country with a very healthy farm stock and agricultural base, could disrupt that base quite considerably, affecting our trade balance and the standard of living of all Australians, if we did not ensure that we protected this country from the importation, either accidentally or deliberately, of exotic pests and diseases. Senator Devereux has referred to foot and mouth disease. An item as innocuous as a pork sausage brought into Australia without proper quarantine screening could, through the introduction of foot and mouth disease, lay waste to our entire pastoral industry. It is estimated that an outbreak of this disease in Australia would cost about $1.6 billion per year, with flow-on effects of eradication and reconstruction costing the national economy over $4 billion per year for several years. That is just one type of disease. There are other diseases. Screw-worm fly is a disease that could have a similar effect to foot and mouth disease if it came into Australia. Newcastle disease could destroy our poultry flock. There are diseases that affect grapes, wheat and citrus that would have a devastating effect on our position as a trading nation.

answer.para: The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) conducted research during 1988 on the public perceptions of quarantine in this country and found that there is negligible awareness of the range of quarantine services provided in Australia by the Quarantine and Inspection Service. Knowledge of its existence virtually does not penetrate the public consciousness at all. It must be observed that no amount of vigilance or expertise on the part of the officers of the AQIS can protect us from a quarantine breach in the face of this apparent public apathy. Thus it is that the Quarantine Service has embarked upon a series of advertisements to try to lift public understanding of what the potential threat to Australia is, not just in economic terms but, as well, in environmental terms, if any of these diseases should pass the barrier. Honourable senators would have seen some of these advertisements in the newspapers recently. Mr President, I display for the Senate one of them. It says:
Want it so bad you'd kill for it?

This is an advertisement that refers to the potentially damaging effects of sausages, meats and cheeses that could be host to the exotic diseases I referred to or woodcarvings and other artefacts that may be purchased in foreign countries and brought into Australia that could be hosts to other sorts of diseases that would affect our housing or our forests.

talk.start.para: —What has been done to educate Torres Strait Islanders in respect of that?

—I will come to that point since you raise it, because it is a very good point. There is the question of what flowers can be brought into this country that would affect our population and industry as well. All those things are aimed at encouraging ordinary Australians to take responsibility themselves, as travellers coming back to this country, to work with our Quarantine and Inspection Service to prevent the importation of those diseases. There is some lightness being made of this in the chamber. I am terribly disappointed about that, because it is an extremely serious thing. One mistake in this area can be of devastating cost to the economy. I hope that the lightness that is being made of this by Opposition senators will not continue in their more sober moments and that they will be examples to the rest of the country of how we, as a trading nation, should conduct ourselves.

answer.para: Senator Crichton-Browne interjected about Torres Strait Islanders. We have in place the northern Australian quarantine strategy. That strategy consists of sending working groups of both Papua New Guinean and Australian quarantine officers throughout the Torres Strait with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander officials and officials from Papua New Guinea to sit down with the various communities in Torres Strait to explain to them what the problems of quarantine are. There was a swing through the whole of the Torres Strait late last year; there is another one planned for August of this year. We have a constant campaign so that indigenous people in the Torres Strait are aware of what the--

talk.start.para: —We'll call a quorum. This is a supplementary question from Senator Crichton-Browne.

—I take great offence at that. I am answering a question. One of Senator Baume's colleagues interjected in the interests of seeking information. I am replying to that. Senator Baume is threatening me that if I do not stop my answer he will impose quorums. I am not going to bow to his intimidations. I am respecting this chamber and helping one of his colleagues. So, Senator Crichton-Browne, we do have that in mind. Christmas Island and other islands in the Indian and Pacific oceans are areas to which we have directed our attention, too. We have recently also signed a memorandum of understanding with the Papua New Guinean Government to make sure that we regulate that zone. In February of this year I signed an intention to form a memorandum of understanding with the Indonesian Government so that we can do the same there.
—That's two quorums.
—I am not going to be intimidated by you.
—Order! There are too many interjections. The Minister will address the Chair and not the interjectors.

—The point that Senator Devereux's question allows me to make is that this is a serious issue, a serious problem, and we enlist the willing cooperation not only of the Opposition but, hopefully, the more intelligent wider Australian community to protect Australian herds and our agricultural industry in this way.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. As the Treasurer's statement last night is silent on the matter, what is presently the Treasury's forecast for inflation in 1989-90?

—I would have thought that Senator Stone had sufficient capacity for original thinking to do something better than repeat the line that I heard his successor-that is, the meretricious player who was flitting across the stage of a ministerial office a few years ago-running on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio this morning. It is not the custom for the Government in mid-year to make public forecasts about major economic indices. Such forecasts are done in the Budget and will be made in the Budget again.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the statement last night mentions the word `inflation' on only three occasions, and in view of the fact that the Treasurer last year in the Budget Speech referred to inflation as our number one economic disease, is the Minister seriously putting to the Senate that the Senate should not be informed as to what the Government, on the basis of the Joint Economic Forecasting Group's papers about a fortnight ago, presently expects the inflation rate of 1989-90 to be?
—It will not be 11 1/2 per cent.
—We can be sure of one thing-it will not be 11 1/2 per cent, as it was when Mr Howard was Treasurer.
—Where was Senator Stone then?

—To be fair to Senator Stone, I must say that he was probably as vigorously opposed to that irresponsible Budget in 1982 as anybody else was. Indeed, I understand that he became quite passionate about it. Sure, we could put out a forecast. Last night we could have said that we expect inflation to be 3 per cent next year. If we did that, we would have been as believable as Senator Stone was when he said, in November 1987, that there was absolutely no doubt that there would be a worldwide recession in 1988.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. In view of the answer given yesterday to Senator McMullan's question on the time being taken for the count in the Australian Capital Territory election, would the Minister give support to the introduction of computerised voting?

answer.ministerial: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS
answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —From time to time enthusiasts advocate that we vote via computer in order to speed up election counts. It is probably overlooked by many of those enthusiasts that, in countries where computers are used overseas, the first past the post system applies. That is a fairly simple system. It is a little more complex in the Senate voting system and even a little more complex again in the modified d'Hondt system.

answer.para: Part of the difficulty is the initial investment. The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, some years ago, looked at the question of costs. Evidence was given that, because we have 8,000 polling booths, the cost would be $40m to $50m. That is based on a simple first past the post system. The more sophisticated software and other requirements to have those things in polling booths make it basically an uneconomic proposal.

A more novel suggestion of course is that we do not have a race meeting on one particular day of the year and we use the totalisator agency boards (TABs) around the country in which to vote. There are some difficulties with that. First, TABs tend to cluster where the punters are; not where the electors are. Secondly, I have noticed, at least in New South Wales-only by driving past them-many of the TABs are in pubs. I do not know that we necessarily want people going into pubs to vote, especially if they are of the more puritan strain.

talk.start.para: —What about Saturdays?
—Senator Maguire shows that he is not a man of the world when he says, `What about Saturdays?'. Fancy cancelling the races for an election! At this stage that is not very likely.

answer.para: After the New South Wales election results had taken a little while to be counted, Mr Nick Greiner got impatient, as people often do, and said, `Maybe we should computerise'. A team that he sent overseas, which included the current Electoral Commissioner and a previous one, investigated this matter and came up with pretty much the same conclusion as everyone else; that, at this stage, computerised voting is not practical and is not a wise investment of public money.

The probable answer is to make the voting system less complicated rather than go to computerisation. That is something we will have to look at seriously. There will come a time-either in the Senate or in the d'Hondt system-when it will take more than two months to count. We should take that into account before we pass legislation here to make voting systems more complex.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In order that everyone can understand and evaluate the implications of last night's financial statement, would the Minister indicate the Government's expectations for interest rates over the next 12 months?

—The answer to the second part of the question is no. If people, including Senator Baume, want some assistance in evaluating last night's statement, let me say that it produced enormous tax cuts and a very strong family package. It produced considerable concessions for pensioners. It leaves a very significant surplus such as this country has not had for 30 years, I suspect. It came about after four years of falling Government spending. Government spending has been lower than at any time during the period of the previous Government. There was never a surplus under the previous Government. The other impact, in evaluating last night's statement, is that it is designed to head off, will succeed in heading off, what otherwise might have been a very difficult wage explosion of the kind which occurred in 1982 and 1974.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why will the Minister not give the people of Australia all the current information on the matter about which I asked, projected interest rates, since they affect every aspect of people's lives, in particular, their capacity to continue to own their own homes? Why will he not give this information so that apparent beneficiaries of last night's statement can know whether they will be net beneficiaries at the end of the day? Does he not consider that every Australian has a right to be in possession of all information presently available on the likely movement of interest rates?

—Senator Peter Baume is developing a Senate version of the melting ice cube theory which was put by his Leader in the other place last night. No government to my knowledge has ever, in any specific terms, speculated about interest rates. I remember that Mr Doug Anthony gave an undertaking about interest rates in the time of the Fraser-Howard Government. He said that if interest rates did not fall by 2 per cent in the particular year, he would eat his hat. He did not honour that promise, but that was par for the course for the previous Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Following the Treasurer's statement last night, what is the net increase in income and wage equivalent for the typical Australian family following the package of tax cuts and family assistance measures handed down last night?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —What is the typical Australian family? I am not sure, so I will give about three examples of representative Australian families. I take it that a family, by definition, comprises at least one parent and at least one child. For a family comprising two children and two parents, but with a single income of $24,000 a year, which is a little below average weekly earnings, the gains from the increase in family allowances, dependent spouse rebate and the changes to the tax rate scale will give them an extra $23.50 a week. As the Treasurer said last night, a dollar in tax cuts or, in this context, one should add tax-free payments, is worth more than a dollar in increased wages. For that family to get the same net benefits from a wage increase, a wage increase of $40 a week would have been required. A very important component of the statement last night, as Senator Button said, is that, as a result of last night's statement, the potential wages explosion that could have occurred because of the very strong demand in the economy has now been headed off. The reason that it will be headed off is that that single income family in receipt of less than average weekly earnings, with two kids, is getting, because of last night's announcement, the equivalent of a $40 a week wage increase.

answer.para: I will give very briefly a couple more examples. For a two-income family with two children, with the principal income earner on an income of $24,000 and the secondary income earner on $10,000-making $34,000 in total-the net increase, because of the tax cut and family allowance increase, would be $23 a week; the equivalent of a $36 a week wage increase, a wage increase distributed in that same proportion between the two income earners. For a sole parent family with two children on an income of $24,000 a year, the net increase would be $23.35 and the wage equivalent required to deliver that net income is almost $40 a week. I will give two other examples. For a single income family with two children and a dependent spouse on a low income-about the bottom of the award wage area-of $17,000 a year, the net increase will be almost $20 a week, or just over $28 a week in pre-tax terms.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I was interested to hear the Minister's figures on the effect on an average family. Since there are many average families under stress in Australia, who might be listening, with great interest, to the Minister's answer, he might turn to the average family, say, in New South Wales with an average mortgage. Can the Minister tell us what that average family has lost in terms of increased payments on that mortgage because of higher interest rates under this Government just in this financial year? Since the Minister is full of examples perhaps he can give us that one.

—As I said before, it is a bit difficult to say with any conviction what is average. We can work out an arithmetical mean. Senator Chaney has raised the question of people who are paying off housing mortgages. For a start such families are not average families or typical families-30 per cent of Australian families are renters; Another 30 per cent are outright owners; 40 per cent are paying off housing loans; and 60 per cent of that 40 per cent had loans prior to the deregulation of housing loan interest rates, in 1987, I think.
—No. That figure is wrong.

—It is certainly more than 50 per cent. They, of course, are not affected by recent interest rate changes. These are not average families or typical families: It is true that people who have recently taken out a housing mortgage loan, particularly those in Sydney where housing prices have escalated very rapidly, are having a struggle. It has always been the case that people who have just taken out a loan to buy their first house in the first few years of repaying that loan always have a bit of a struggle. There is nothing unusual about that. Because interest rates have been somewhat higher than normal in the last six months or so, they are having a bit more of a struggle. However, to such people last night's economic statement will provide them with significantly more disposable income in order to meet their obligations. The alternative to last night's statement would have been a wage explosion. The Opposition knows all about wages explosions. It presided over one in 1981 and 1982. The only reason interest rates did not hit 20 per cent was that they were still regulated.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Clearly the Minister is debating the question. He has moved off the question which was asked and is now indulging his usual high spirits. I ask you, Mr President, to direct him back to the question.
—Has the Minister finished his answer?
—I have finished, Mr President.

—I ask another supplementary question. Does the Minister deny that in Sydney an average mortgage is in excess of $80,000 and that a person with a mortgage of that figure would have seen an increase in weekly payments of more than $40 a week? Since, as he points out, 30 per cent of people are renters, is he in a position to tell us about the movement of rents during this financial year?

—I do not know what the average mortgage is in Sydney. I doubt that it is as high as $80,000. It certainly would not be that high if we take into account the 30 per cent of people who own houses outright. I do not think that proportion is very different in Sydney from what it is anywhere else. I repeat: if we had opted instead for a wages explosion a la 1981 and 1982 and unregulated interest rates, interest rates would have been above 20 per cent.
—I raise again, Mr President, the same point of order.
—Order! There is no point of order. It is an area of the Minister's portfolio.

—My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security relates to the announcement last night that child payments will in future be adjusted for inflation. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the significance of the announcement by the Treasurer?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: —The importance of last night's statement is that, in essence, it is an historic announcement. It is one that this Government is extremely proud of. It is historic because it gives on-going benefits to most Australian families; it is historic because before last night no government and no parliament of this country had placed children first; and it is historic because we have done so. Not only have we done that but we are also committed to maintaining the value of payments to families with children. The basic strength of our commitment is that all child payments will be automatically adjusted for inflation. Whether it be the family allowance, family allowance supplements, additional pensions and benefits, the mothers/guardians allowance, the child disability allowance, double orphans pensions and multiple birth payments, they will all be automatically adjusted for inflation.

answer.para: As a nation I think we like to pride ourselves on putting our children first. But I do not think we can fairly say that before last night's statement we have actually done so. Not only have we now achieved benchmarks but we have also indexed the child-related payments to ensure security and protection. We are the first government in the history of Australia to commit ourselves to maintaining the real value of payments of families with children.

In recent days the Opposition has made a number of claims that it is the party for ordinary families. But our performance can very easily be compared with that of the Opposition. In seven years in government the coalition made only one increase in the family allowance and that was in 1982 in a period of economic disaster. In this context, the Government's package is quite historic. It is historic because it is the largest increase in the family allowance in our history; it prevents the erosion of payments ever occurring again. But more importantly than that, it is part of this Government's long term commitment in this area, a commitment which was very well spelt out in Social Security Review Paper No. 1 in 1986. That paper committed this Government to achieving short term measures to accommodate people most in need and long term measures to restore fair income distribution to families with children and, more importantly, to protecting from inflation families with children.

As I said at the start, this is an historic package and we are proud of it. We have delivered in terms of achieving the benchmarks that we set out to achieve for low income families; we have delivered, as I said, because it is the biggest increase in family allowances in our country's history; and we have delivered in the sense that we are protecting child-related payments from inflation. In closing, I stress the point that all these achievements have been made in the context of a long term commitment by this Government to achieve protection and reform in this whole area.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations. How does the Government define the `sensible wages outcomes' referred to last night on page 2 of the Treasurer's statement? By `sensible', does the Government mean the maintenance of an overall rate of wage increase roughly double that of some of our major trading partners, including Japan and the United States of America?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —Senator Lewis can make these comparisons at any time. Last year the Opposition was hot to trot on making comparisons between the inflation rate in Australia and the inflation rate in the United Kingdom. It has dropped off that this year because it does not serve its purpose. Last year it was also hot to trot on making comparisons in the inflation rate between Australia and the United States of America. It has dropped off that, too, because it does not suit it this year. Now the honourable senator asks me whether the rate of wage increases in Australia is higher than in Japan. I believe it is. But the wage outcome is sensible in the sense that it takes account of existing situations in Australia and does not ignore them, as the stupid wages outcome under his previous Government did in 1981 and 1982. They sent this country into a recession and sent hundreds of thousands of people on to the streets unemployed. That is the difference between a sensible wage outcome and a silly wage outcome.

answer.para: The honourable senator wants to make comparisons in terms of wages, particularly in the manufacturing sector. It is true that the rate of growth may be higher than in Japan under this wage outcome. The fact of the matter is, however, that wages in manufacturing in this country are about one-third of what they are in Japan. If we have a competitive disadvantage against Japan, I do not believe it is because of wages; it is for a variety of other reasons in terms of management competence and a whole range of other issues-including productivity, which the honourable senator might like to ask me about. With respect, I think the question in that sense is misconceived.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister then approve overall rates of wage increases on an average basis rather than allowing those industries which do manage to increase their productivity to increase the size of wages in relation to their particular work force? Does the Minister, on the basis of what he has just told the Senate, believe that the Government's policy will prevent a wage break-out this year?

—The answer to the last part of the question is yes. My answer to the question of whether I approve the rates of wage increases, as outlined in the economic statement last night, is yes, in current economic circumstances. I include in those circumstances the desire of the vast majority of employers, I think, to pay larger wage increases than those. So in current economic circumstances, my answer to that question is yes.

question.block.title: WORKS OF ART IN PARLIAMENT HOUSE

talk.start.para: —My question is to you, Mr President. I draw your attention to the artwork in Parliament House, which I think is quite splendid, covering, as we know, pottery, painting, embroidery, tapestry, sculpture and more. However, over recent days I have noticed that three swan sculptures on the second floor have gone missing. Could it be that the birds have flown? Could you tell me where they have gone and why, and if and when they will return. I think they were one of the most appreciated works of art around this place. Further, do we have or will we get a catalogue of the artwork in Parliament House, particularly for the thousands of visitors who come not only to see the building and the Parliament but also to enjoy the artwork in this place?

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —The artwork in question consists of three freestanding swans constructed in timber, which were originally located on the western side of the mural hall. I have been informed that whilst the swans were occasionally moved from their original location, they in fact never finished up in a watery resting place, which was one of the rumours that went around. Whilst the artwork obviously made an impact on people passing by, parliamentary officials were concerned that the movement of the swans without due regard to the fragility of the wings could cause damage. The swans have not been removed from the building, but placed in a storeroom while an alternative location is found for them where they can be on static display for the enjoyment of all.

interject.para: I take this opportunity to remind all persons working in Parliament House of the value and uniqueness of the art works, gifts and craft works collected and displayed in the building. It is our responsibility to preserve and protect them for those who come after us and for the Australian public visiting the building. As far as the catalogue is concerned, I believe there is one. It has been prepared. I will make inquiries as to whether it can be made available to all senators and people coming through the building.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Government or any of its agencies done any studies to establish what impact on consumer spending and the balance of payments will result from the $5 billion ephemeral pre-election tax hand-out, plus the wage and welfare rises announced last night? What do these studies show? How does this large stimulus to consumer spending square with the Minister's statement in the Senate last Friday that `the major responsibility of the Government is to reduce the present level of demand'? Why has the Government repudiated what the Minister himself says is its major responsibility?

—I find some of the rhetoric of this question extraordinary. What I think Senator Baume might be confronted with following last night's package is what T.S. Eliot once called `the growing horror of nothing to think about'. Today, after having been bouncing around here for months on end talking about what he was going to do for families, he seems to be objecting to what the Government has done. That may be right, because his leader told the people last year he would do a lot more; he just did not explain how he would finance it. I will find out for Senator Baume whether any studies have been done. I think it is very unlikely that the behavioural scientists' skills run to determining what the likely pattern of expenditure is going to be in the last half of 1989. But I will find out the answer.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate-presumably he is a member of the Cabinet and other important parts of the Hawke Government-seriously telling this chamber that he does not know whether the Treasury, for example, the Reserve Bank or any other governmental agency has no idea and has done no work to establish what the impact would be of a $5 billion boost to consumer spending out of tax cuts alone? If he is seriously telling us that, I ask what other work, if any, the Government has done to see what the consequences on the economy will be of its package last night?

—I do not want to go on with this debate. Frankly, I am seriously telling Senator Baume that, and I said that if there is anything that has been done I will try to find out about it; but I think it is most unlikely.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer to recent comments by Tasmanian Premier Gray, who claimed that the Tasmanian Government paid proper regard to environmental concerns over the proposed Wesley Vale pulp mill. How does this claim match with the recent assertions of the Chair of Noranda, Mr Adam Zimmerman, that the Tasmanian Government was tiresome and provincial and that the Federal Government demanded open-ended and virtually impossible environmental conditions for the project?
—And the Federal Government, the Federal Minister, lied.
—Order! Senator Archer will withdraw that.
—I withdraw.

answer.ministerial: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES
answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: —I did notice the comments of Premier Gray, who has been working pretty hard in the last few weeks to try to rewrite history to cover up the less than glorious role he played in the Wesley Vale saga.
—What about your role?

—I will get to my role. As for the Chairman of Noranda, he has been attempting, in the last week in particular, to cover up the history of intransigence that has marked his company's attitude to the Wesley Vale story. I want to quote what Premier Gray and his Minister, Mr Groom, had to say only a few weeks ago. On 1 February the Launceston Examiner reported the Premier as saying that the guidelines that his Government had developed for the Wesley Vale pulp mill were achievable and not for negotiation. The Premier accused the joint venturers of `holding a gun at the Government's head'. He questioned whether they were serious about the project. The next day the Deputy Premier in Tasmania, Mr Groom, went even further. According to a report in the Examiner on 2 February Mr Groom:

answer.para: suggested the developers were trying to sabotage the pulp mill, by employing tactics which he described-
that is Mr Groom, Senator Archer's man-
as ``extraordinary'' and an indictment on their bona fides.
The report stated that Mr Groom:
revealed that experts from the joint venture Canadian partner, Noranda, had told a full Cabinet meeting this month that the environment guidelines-NBH says can't be met-could in fact be met.

In case anyone wants to doubt the veracity of those reports in the Examiner, let me turn to the Hobart Mercury of the same day, 2 February, which carried a very similar report. Mr Groom accused the company of `underhand tactics'. It stated:
Mr Groom would not specify what those tactics were, but said if the project was called off it would be for some reason other than the environmental guidelines.
``I sense they are not particularly keen to get a result,'' he said.

That assumes greater significance now that the companies have walked away. I think the question to be answered is what really happened in the two days after the Tasmanian Premier, the Deputy Premier and the environment Minister, Mr Hodgman, all confirmed that the guidelines were achievable and were not for negotiation.

talk.start.para: —They were telling the truth.

—The answer to that is pretty obvious. North Broken Hill and Noranda applied the corporate blowtorch and the Tasmanian Government went to water-a craven capitulation if ever there was one. Forget concerns for the environment, the fishermen and the farmers! Forty changes of definition were then made to the guidelines, all to suit the companies. No longer were these reinterpreted guidelines the toughest in the world. Senator Button, Mr Keating and I took all of 10 minutes to discover that in a meeting with the joint venturers when they admitted they could go further. That was not hard; they admitted the guidelines were not the toughest. They admitted there was better technology and they could go further. They just did not want to be required to do so. When Senator Archer talks about who is telling the truth let me say that on the record from the Tasmanian Premier and his Deputy Premier, it is obvious where the untruths were being told. It is also obvious where the truths were being told; they have only come from the Commonwealth.

answer.para: On 18 October last year Senator Button announced a package to assist that mill. The Commonwealth always wanted to do that. It included confirmation that the project would qualify for accelerated depreciation and approval for the Tasmanian Government to borrow extra loan funds to pay for various infrastructure. There was an attempt by the Commonwealth to speed up the process by agreeing to the Commonwealth and Tasmania conducting the environmental impact study concurrently. The Commonwealth did all it reasonably could to get the project off the ground, but from the Tasmanian Deputy Premier's own lips came the words, `If the project does not proceed, it will not be because of tough environmental guidelines'. Maybe Noranda ought to be asked what the real agenda was. Was it the fact that in Canada the Government was closing in on it as well and it did not want tough guidelines here that may one day be imposed on it at home? Unfortunately I have sad news for it-the Canadian Government is catching up with it and tougher guidelines are on the way.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Treasurer's statement last night when he heroically claimed that as a result of the proposed tax cuts `personal income tax payers will now be paying less than if we had indexed the tax scales for inflation since 1983'. Has the Minister seen the article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Daryl Dixon which shows that some middle income taxpayers will need more than what the Government provided by last night's tax cuts merely to compensate for the impact of inflation since 1982-83? Will the Minister table figures to prove the Treasurer's extraordinary assertion?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —I have not seen Daryl Dixon's article but the comment made by the Treasurer last night-and I will check this with the Treasurer-is, I believe, based on a proportion of income paid in tax for all taxpayers. There is not necessarily an inconsistency between that and a taxpayer on a particular income who may be paying more than he might have paid at some previous time. I believe that is the basis of the Treasurer's statement, but I will check it.

answer.para: In closing, last night this Government announced the biggest tax cuts, the biggest family package in history, there were major concessions to pensioners, and we will still bring down a Budget surplus in excess of $5 billion. Until last year nobody in Australia very seriously contemplated there being a Federal Budget surplus. The reason that we have been able to do all those seemingly incompatible things is that we have kept expenditure nailed right down for four years-four years of falling Commonwealth Government expenditure, the sort of thing those opposite talk about and were never able to do.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer in which he indicated that income tax collected is across the whole board and refers to all personal taxpayers. But does he understand that the article by Daryl Dixon today covers the whole range of income tax earnings, earnings that will be subject to income tax, and therefore includes all those people, and in respect of individual cases clearly shows that it does not cover the tax that has been lost through non-indexation since 1983?
—I have already said that I have not seen Mr Dixon's article.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. It refers to page 5 of the Treasurer's statement last night in which referring to what low income earners would receive, the Treasurer stated, `Subsequent award restructuring and supplementary wage payments will deliver an additional $40 a week giving a total wage equivalent increase of $64 a week'. Can the Minister guarantee that this will occur and, if he can, how can he guarantee that that will occur and over what time frame?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —I do not think that under the restructuring principles one can guarantee that this will occur. It is the wish and the intention of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) representing the unions that it will occur.
—The Treasurer said it will deliver.

—The honourable senator asked me a question which had that little hook in it about whether the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission still has a function. Of course it does, but with parties such as the Commonwealth Government arguing for that to occur, with the ACTU arguing for that to occur and I believe with very little employer organisation resistance to that occurring under the restructuring principles, it is fair to say that it will be delivered.

answer.para: The second point I was asked about was on timing. Under the restructuring principles those payments will occur when award restructuring takes place. All one can say is that the first payments will be received in the latter half of this calendar year, and the second payment will be received some time about the middle of next year. That involves negotiations by the parties, and particularly the unions and the employers, in relation to these matters, but that is what will happen.

talk.start.para: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to reports about the likely establishment of free trade zones along the far east coast of the Soviet Union. What is the Australian Government's reaction to these proposals? Does the Government plan to encourage Australian companies to participate in joint venture arrangements with the Soviet Union in these zones? Given the Victorian Government's abandoned joint venture plans for a $400m aluminium mill development in China, what measures will the Australian Government undertake to ensure that any joint ventures in Soviet free trade zones will not encounter these types of problems?

—I would prefer to take the question on notice rather than to give an incomplete answer at this stage. I would only say that the prospect of free trade zones, be it in the Soviet far east or anywhere else, is one that the Australian Government welcomes as part of our general approach to increasing the volume and quality of trade world wide, and more particularly in our region. The fact that some of the previously centrally planned economies are now getting into the business of Marxist-Leninist market-driven economics is a wholly salutary development and one we applaud in the Soviet Union as elsewhere. I will give the honourable senator a more considered reply at a later stage.

—I address my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and again it concerns Wesley Vale. How does the Minister respond to claims that the Federal Government intervened in Wesley Vale only at the eleventh hour? When was the company first told of what was required and did it comply with those requirements? Secondly, how many times did the Commonwealth consult with the joint venturers and the Tasmanian Government?

answer.ministerial: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES
answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: —Mr Presi- dent--
—The Minister has already been asked that question and answered it last week.

—I have been asked several questions about this. I have not been asked this question. Nonetheless, I will attempt to respond to Senator Aulich. I can give some idea to Senator Aulich today about some of the chronology of events, although in terms of the last part of his question as to how many times consultations occurred between the Commonwealth and the joint venturers and the Tasmanian Government, I shall attempt to obtain for him a full chronology of events and make it available to Senator Aulich and to any senators who may be interested. As I said in answer to Senator Puplick yesterday, on 11 July last year officials of my Department met representatives of the joint venturers. On 25 July last year again those officials met with the joint venturers and officials from the Tasmanian Government. The Tasmanian department had been supplied with about 30 pages of draft guidelines for preparing the environmental impact statement. Those guidelines were discussed in some detail.
—What are your guidelines?

—These were guidelines for the environmental impact statement. By the time the period of public review of the environmental impact statement closed in early December, it was clear that there were some major environmental questions that remained unanswered-not just to the Commonwealth, but at that time to the Tasmanian Government. On 7 December, after consultation with the Commonwealth, the Tasmanian Government wrote to North Broken Hill Peko Ltd outlining 85 matters which the State and Federal governments considered had either `been inadequately addressed or not addressed at all' in the environmental impact statement.

answer.para: The joint venturers replied with a letter on 3 January and provided what could be termed answers in an addendum. I shall provide Senator Aulich with one example of just how inadequate these answers were. The joint venturers had been asked to outline the studies which would be done to determine the final design and location of the outfall site-not an unimportant or insignificant matter in this mill, given that the proposal was to dump 13 tonnes of organochlorins into the sea in Bass Strait at a point where there was very little tidal movement. It was a serious matter. The Government got a seven-word answer: The assumed depth is about 20 metres. That was the whole answer to that question about what studies would be done.

If one looks at the letter that the Commonwealth sent to North Broken Hill on 8 February, we sought clarification again on what one could call some pretty important matters: dioxin emissions, chlorine dioxide substitution levels and the emission of odours. The Department asked for a response as soon as possible. That letter of 8 February was never answered. That was totally ignored. One wonders what sort of attitude is being displayed by the company when it ignores both the Tasmanian Government and the Commonwealth Government in the pursuit of their legitimate concerns. The joint venturers knew what information the Federal Government and the State Government required and simply refused to supply it. They admitted that the guidelines could be tougher. They did not want to accept either Government's right to impose those tougher guidelines on them. The companies and the Tasmanian Government simply did not take seriously the firm and proper process that was in place for assessing the project. The Commonwealth took the process seriously. I only wish that others involved in negotiations had taken it in a similarly serious vein.

answer.ministerial: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES
answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: —I want to take further an answer to a question asked of me a couple of days ago by Senator Newman. Major-General Sanderson's review is being coordinated with a second but interrelated review being conducted by Rear-Admiral Ralph. The aim of the Ralph review is to develop a case for submission to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal seeking to address the compression of salaries to senior officers of lieutenant-colonel equivalent to major-general inclusive within current wage fixing principles. The case is to conform with the structural efficiency principle enunciated in the national wage case decision of 12 August 1988. It is envisaged that senior officer salary increases would be commensurate with manpower savings of about 10 per cent to 15 per cent. Ultimately the claim will be dependent on manpower reductions achieved by the Sanderson review and savings therefrom.

answer.para: The broader implications of the Sanderson review will have to be assessed when the review is complete. There may or may not be consequential changes to Senior Executive Service positions in the Department following the review. I would not like to pre-empt the outcome of the review. The senior staffing of the Department is under constant review. Since May 1987 there has been a reduction of eight Senior Executive Service positions in Defence, exclusive of the Government Aircraft Factory and the Williamstown dockyard, which have been severed from the Department. The amalgamation of capital procurement and defence logistics will result in the reduction of at least one level 6 position.

proctext.para: That the time for presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on assistance to the sugar industry be extended to 8 May 1989.

debate.title: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

speech.speaker: Schacht Sen C.C.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present a report entitled Australia's Relations with the South Pacific, together with the transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

I shall make some very brief remarks because I know there is pressure of other business. In asking the Senate to take note of the report, I draw attention to the fact that the report is the result of nearly two years of work. There are 46 major recommendations. In my view, the report should be taken in conjunction, in many respects, with the report of the Committee that was tabled recently on Australia's overseas aid. There are in a sense cross-references in that area. I also draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that, in the near future, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade will begin a reference on Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea, which is an ongoing area of the Committee's work generally with Australia and the South Pacific.

I also draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the Committee had the opportunity in June of last year to visit eight countries in the South Pacific in 18 days. That delegation of some nine members plus the Secretary of the Committee was extremely worthwhile. The Committee appreciates the assistance the Australian Government gave in providing a plane to take us to some of the smaller countries of the South Pacific to make it an efficient trip as far as time was concerned. I believe that visit to those countries proved the advantage of standing committees being able to get first-hand experience. In major reports such as this, in the future, though it is obviously costly to the Parliament and the Government, those trips should be funded. I would point out that the trip was not a junket around the South Pacific. The Committee worked extremely hard in visiting those countries.

I place on record the appreciation of myself and, I am sure, other members of the South Pacific Subcommittee for the assistance of the secretariat of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and in particular the Secretary, Joanne Towner, who worked very hard to put into some order all the many ideas and views that members of the Committee had, in helping to draft the report, and in her role as Secretary of the Committee in assisting in preparation for the visit to the South Pacific countries in June of last year.

I mention that, although under the Standing Orders the Subcommittee effectively goes out of existence with the tabling of this report. Members of the Committee, under another name or an informal description, will be visiting New Zealand and New Caledonia next week for a period of about eight days. Again, I think that the Parliament and the Australian Government, in providing the funds for that visit for the members of the Committee, will get very good value in further enhancing our contacts and relations with New Zealand and the developing situation for independence in New Caledonia.
I seek leave to table the remarks made in the House of Representatives by Mr David Charles, the honourable member for Isaacs and Chairman of the South Pacific Subcommittee.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

speech.para: Leave not granted.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: —I want to speak to the motion that the Senate take note of the report. Whilst I do not intend to speak at length, as the Senate is pressed by its Estimates responsibilities, I think it is important to make a few points. The first is that I commend the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade as a whole for the work it has done in this regard. Of course, in doing so, I commend the staff, the officials and all of those who contributed by representation or otherwise to what I think is a most important reference work. I also concur with what Senator Schacht said, that the report ought to be read in conjunction with the previous report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on aid, and I commend the fact that the Committee is now going to consider Papua New Guinea (PNG) in greater depth.

speech.para: It seems to me that in many ways the Committee is doing the work that the Government itself should have done. One sees in this report a detailed explanation of the problems that are facing the island states of the South Pacific, the problems in the relationship between Australia and those island states and the constructive attempt to put forward positive proposals and actions that Australia might take for the benefit of both the island states and us. That would be a useful tool at least for the next government if this Government is not prepared to take action. It is a matter of regret to me and the Opposition that the Government, even under the new Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), whose first trip was to the South Pacific, is not prepared to put down detailed statements in this chamber of its acknowledgment of the difficulties facing the island states and its proposals on what action should be taken to improve the situation. So I believe that this document produced by the Parliament will be of benefit to governments.

I recall that when this Government first came to office the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, said-and I was present at the speech he gave at the Australian National University-that the focus of the Government in foreign affairs would be on our own region. Of course, in practice, that was not the focus of the Government. It focused on the world stage, on the major international fora, and in many ways neglected the South Pacific region, which is obviously our most immediate concern and responsibility in international relations. There were signs at that time of growing problems within the region, problems which have now been detailed in many ways in this report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. There were ongoing problems concerning health issues, educational inadequacies and poverty, all of which this Government should have been aware of. Equally, the signs were there of growing political strain. Frustrations had developed out of the fact that the states were now legally independent yet in many ways remained dependent, particularly upon Australia, and conflicts arose out of our failure to understand the need, in our education of them, for them to comply with our democratic institutions-the Westminster system and so forth=mand to balance that against their respective histories and cultures. I regret to say that these strains were ignored by this Government. It was a situation of benign neglect at best.

The position was even worse with Papua New Guinea. It went beyond benign neglect to actions that were positively taken to affect detrimentally the political and economic stability of that country. I refer, of course, to the decision of the Government in 1986 to slash unilaterally $10m off the agreed aid program between Australia and PNG just after that aid program had been renegotiated with reductions. So we saw a situation where PNG, our closest neighbour, had developed a loss of confidence in Australia which it was prepared to project internationally. I was present at a speech given in Washington DC where the Deputy Prime Minister of PNG said that he would not have expected that of Australia. The extent to which the island states were losing confidence in Australia and in what they thought was Australia's special relationship with them came through to me.

In regard to benign neglect, we have to put this report into the context of the Government's ignorance of what was occurring in Fiji. The report focuses to some extent on Fiji, but in the case of Fiji the Australian Government was totally ignorant of the political developments as they were occurring and was unable to predict in any way the first coup. In fact, our head of mission was out of the country at the time. Then, of course, after receiving assurances from this Government that everything was going well, the second coup occurred. That was a major indictment, I would respectfully suggest, of this Government's intelligence resources and understanding of what was happening in the region. The Government had no idea-which is probably worse-of how to respond to the events. That demonstrated again how out of touch it had become. We found in the press that the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, wanted to send troops into Fiji. Goodness only knows what the troops would have done when they got there-even if we had had the capacity to get them there, which we did not.

The Government does not seem to have understood the significance of the development of ethnic groups within the region. It dismisses the Melanesian spearhead group. But that group is evidence of growing ethnic solidarity and frustration by the island states with the big powers of the South Pacific Forum, the principal player within the forum being Australia, and with the paternalistic approach that the Government has shown.

I move to the difficulties that have come out of the Government's poor judgment of our relationship with France. There has been a refusal for a long time by this Government to recognise that France is a major player in the Pacific. One can say what one likes in the United Nations, but France is going to remain a major power and an influence upon peace, stability and economic development within the Pacific. It was continually condemned in relation to New Caledonia by this Government in a simplistic and very shallow way. The Government had to end up eating humble pie when it found, because of our economic strife, that there was no alternative but to reinstate uranium sales to France. Then the Government had to address how it would relate in a new relationship with France in the Pacific. What we had been saying all along was that if the Government had related to France in a more sensible and mature way we would have had a greater capacity to influence events in New Caledonia, particularly for the benefit of the Kanak people. Instead of that, we were in fact locked out of the debate by this Government's approach.

Continuing to put this report in its context, we then had the appointment of a new Foreign Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, and I very quickly welcome the fact that he chose to make his first trip as Minister to the South Pacific. But the Opposition was disappointed when he returned that he did not put down a statement in the Parliament but chose instead to speak to the foreign correspondents club in Sydney and tell them what had suddenly apparently become a newly thought out policy on the South Pacific. This was his policy that he called constructive commitment, a policy which is clearly a play on words on the Crocker American policy on South Africa of constructive engagement. However, apparently during the course of his trip around the South Pacific, Senator Evans decided that our new approach should be that of constructive commitment. The Opposition thought that he should have come into the Parliament and explained what he intended by that, how the policy would develop and how it would be of benefit to the island states and our relationship with the island states, But we were not afforded that courtesy. There is no evidence that that policy has been thought through. It seems to be just another example of `it seemed to be a good idea at the time'. After having got a copy of the speech Senator Evans gave in Sydney I was surprised but pleased to see that he was prepared to acknowledge his lack of knowledge of events in the South Pacific. What surprised me was an acknowledgment of the Government's failure to properly comprehend what was happening in the region. Senator Evans repeated the sort of assurances--

talk.start.para: —I apologise to Senator Hill, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I rise on a point of order. Is it in order for the Senate to be considering a report of a parliamentary committee, copies of which are not available to senators who have requested them? They are not available in my office. I have requested a copy to be brought to me in the Senate and none has come. I believe that it is not in order for the Senate to be debating a report, copies of which are not available to honourable senators.
—There is no point of order. It is the responsibility of the Committee to make available those reports.

—That is a disappointment. I stress again that this is a very important report in relation to a region that is critically important to Australia's interests. As Senator Harradine knows, by the time we come back in a fortnight, the Parliament will have moved on to new business and someone such as Senator Harradine, who has had a long involvement in a positive way in relation to the region, should have the opportunity to see the advice that we are giving to the Parliament and to respond to it.

speech.para: I will continue with what I was saying. I will not be too much longer. I was trying to compare the positive, constructive efforts of this Committee with the Government's neglect and failure in relation to the region. I am referring to the best information that I can get-Senator Evans does not report to the Parliament on these matters-and that is a speech he gave in Sydney in which he outlined the Government's new approach to the region: that of constructive commitment. In that speech he repeated the sort of undertakings that Mr Hayden gave some years before that there would be a focus by this Government on the region. He said that it is the most important international responsibility of Australia. He used the words `our most immediate priority' in his speech. All I can say to that is that we hope that in due course there will be much greater substance added to his rhetoric than we saw added to the rhetoric of his predecessor, Mr Hayden.

I hope that this report helps the Government in its approach to Fiji. The Opposition is concerned that we see no signs of an improving situation in Fiji, whether it is looked at economically, politically or constitutionally. Honourable senators will remember the Government advising the Parliament that a new constitution would soon be enacted in Fiji. That new constitution has not come to pass and the situation remains as worrying to us as it was at the time of the unfortunate overthrow of democratic government. Senator Evans cancelled his visit to Fiji at the last moment when access was not given to its former Prime Minister. Of course, we all remember Mr Hawke saying that Australia would not be threatened in this way. Because of the inconsistencies we now do not know exactly what the Government's policy is on Fiji. Parts of an aid program were given on the basis of positive changes which were said to have occurred but which have not occurred. The other half of the aid has now not been given because the Government says that those positive changes have not occurred. Our approach to Fiji seems to be a mess.

Of greater concern-I hope that the Government will get some use and guidance out of this report-is Australia's approach to the problems that are occurring in Papua New Guinea (PNG). We are much more concerned than this Government-this is apparent from an answer that Senator Evans gave to a question of mine in the last few days-at events occurring in PNG. The concern on our part is that Australia is not using its best endeavours to assist continued economic and political stability in that country. Last year, after returning from a brief fact finding visit to PNG, I advocated that we could do more to help with the law and order position that the Government of PNG wanted; we could do more to help with economic development, particularly in legal ways-PNG was drafting a new mining Act. We have the experience to help in this regard. We could assist it with its tourism, help it to build its economic base and particularly be of much greater assistance in relation to education. These are positive programs that receive, I regret to say, no positive response from this Government. We are disappointed in the Government's record in relation to the Pacific states in our region. I hope the Government will read this report in relation to Fiji and Papua New Guinea and the problems in Vanuatu and Nauru, which this Government seems to be totally overlooking.

If the Government needs any further help, I can only commend to it the Opposition's new foreign policy statement. Senator Evans, in answer to a dorothy dixer the other day, decided that he would have a bit of a go at our foreign policy. I presume that the Senate will extend to me the same courtesy. I will remind honourable senators of the key points in relation to the South Pacific, interestingly most of which have been developed in this Parliamentary Committee's report on the region. We are not the only ones who have recognised the shortcomings and are putting forward ideas. Upon coming to government, which does not seem to be far off, we will be examining the establishment of a South Pacific development bank to strengthen regional investment and economic cooperation. We will also be considering special programs of assistance for the smaller states. When Senator Harradine gets the opportunity to read this report, he will find that the Parliament says there should be special programs in relation to Kiribati and Tuvalu.

We will be working in close consultation with the island states to provide shared facilities for diplomatic representation in Canberra. Honourable senators know the diplomatic assistance that Australia has given under policy that was initiated by former Prime Minister Fraser to help with facilities for the island states in New York, in relation to the United Nations. We will also give support for regional networks concerned with information gathering on maritime surveillance, commercial use of the seabed, drugs and arms trafficking and terrorism. We will be moving to give increased training opportunities for island states officials, particularly in such areas as diplomacy, negotiations with foreign commercial enterprises, public administration and management, exploitation of ocean resources, parliamentary and legal processes, and encountering terrorism, drugs and arms smuggling. We will be upgrading our defence assistance programs to the South Pacific. We will be offering increased consultation, more frequent exchanges at ministerial and senior official levels, interchange of senior public servants, exchanges of parliamentary delegations and education and training programs. I commend the ideas and initiatives of the Opposition to the Senate. I thank the Senate for giving me the opportunity to speak to this most important report.
