debate.title: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —As Deputy Chairman, I present the report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation was established by the Parliament on 17 October 1988 to inquire into and report on the 16 Bills that go to make up what is known as the corporations legislation package. Collectively, they encompass the regulation and operation of corporations and securities law in Australia. The Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, whose brainchild the Bills are, claims that they collectively comprise the largest single legislative package since Federation-some 1,200 pages of drafting by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel.

These Bills were introduced into the Parliament in the House of Representatives on 25 May 1988, at the death knock of the conclusion of the autumn session. They were debated, if that is the right word, by the House of Representatives on 28 and 29 September 1988 and passed, along with no fewer than 280 amendments moved by the Government. The amended Bills were introduced into the Senate on 14 October 1988. They have not been debated here, pending completion and presentation of the Joint Select Committee's report. They are currently listed for debate in the next sitting week of the Senate, commencing 2 May.

When the Bills were introduced into the Senate, the Opposition sought to refer them to a joint committee with wide ranging terms of reference. That motion was defeated by the Government with the support of the Australian Democrats. Instead, the Senate approved more narrow terms of reference for the Committee. In the event, and for reasons explained in the report, the Committee decided not to take too narrow an approach to these terms.

The 16 Bills that were the subject of the Committee's inquiry comprise three principal Bills, the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) Bill, the Corporations Bill and the Close Corporations Bill, plus 13 Bills relating to various levies and taxes. The submissions to the Committee and the evidence that it took at public hearings were concerned overwhelmingly with the ASC Bill and the Corporations Bill. The Committee's report reflects that.

The Corporations Bill, which is based largely on the existing Companies Code but with many significant differences, is by far the larger, more technical and detailed Bill of the two. With one major exception-namely, where the power to make a declaration of unacceptable conduct in the course of a takeover should lie-the Committee was generally, though not always, unanimous in its views on the proposals relating to the Corporations Bill. I emphasise that all members of the Committee agreed that there was need for some significant changes in the legislative framework for the regulation of the companies and securities industry in Australia and were agreed on what many of those changes should be.

By far the greater difficulties in reaching agreement within the Committee lay in its consideration of the Australian Securities Commission Bill. This Bill proposes a completely new institutional framework for the regulation of corporations and securities law in Australia. It would establish a national centralised body, the Australian Securities Commission, to replace the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). The cooperative arrangements which have operated during the past near decade would be abandoned; in particular, the Ministerial Council, which comprises the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth, the six State Attorneys-General and the Attorney-General of the Northern Territory, would cease to exist. The ASC would be supported and accompanied by several other bodies, notably an advisory committee and a corporations and securities panel.

The basic question with which the Committee was confronted was whether the agreed desirable changes which are contained essentially in the Corporations Bill required the fundamental structural changes contained in the ASC Bill or whether they could be satisfactorily accommodated within the existing cooperative scheme based around the NCSC and the Ministerial Council.

The Committee's recommendations on all aspects of the proposed legislative package are contained in the second chapter of the report. A majority of the Committee, the five Government members plus Senator Macklin, strongly supported the fundamental structural changes proposed. The four coalition members of the Committee were equally strongly of the view that the cooperative scheme should remain in place and that the changes proposed in the Corporations Bill could readily be embraced by the cooperative scheme.

The views of the coalition members are set out in a dissenting report to the main report. In that dissenting report we state that to establish a completely new structure, as proposed by the Attorney-General, `would be to embark on a legislative adventure of monumental folly'. We also make it quite clear that we believe that improvements can and should be made to the cooperative arrangements. For example, we would support a proposal that the Federal Attorney-General be the permanent chairman of the Ministerial Council. We also support the establishment of a parliamentary standing committee on corporations and securities.

Today is not the occasion to go into detail about the specific provisions of either the ASC Bill or the Corporations Bill. First, I am mindful of the need for Senate Estimates committees to commence their hearings as soon as possible and, secondly, detailed debate on the essentially technical proposals contained in the Corporations Bill would better await the debate at both the second reading stage and the committee stage of the Bills when the Senate resumes its consideration presumably in early May. The report will provide a major input into those debates. Thirdly, I am very mindful that other senators, including my Joint Select Committee colleagues Senator Alston, Senator McMullan, Senator Cooney and Senator Macklin, may wish to speak to the motion before the Chair.

With one diversion, I propose to confine the remainder of my comments to the reasons for my strong rejection of the ASC Bill proposal. In doing so I will draw heavily on the dissenting report which I and my three coalition colleagues signed and which I commend to all senators and members before the debate on the Bills resumes. The diversion is to place on record a tribute to the Chairman of the Committee, Mr Ron Edwards, for the courteous, even-handed and efficient manner in which he conducted our business at all times. I also want to give particular thanks to the Secretary of our Committee, Andrew Sneddon, and his team, especially Peter Short, John O'Donovan and Annette Fisher, for their absolutely herculean efforts in handling the administrative requirements of the Committee, and the initial drafting of the Committee's report and its preparation for presentation today. I believe we set them an almost impossible task. The results indicate that the almost impossible can prove possible. The Committee also benefited greatly during its deliberations from the assistance and advice it received from Brian O'Callaghan of the Attorney-General's Department, Mark Dickens of the NCSC, and Michael Heffernan of the Australian Stock Exchange.

Let me turn to the dissenting report. I emphasise that it relates only to the ASC Bill. However, that is the key Bill because it will determine the structural framework within which the regulation of companies and securities will operate in the future. The first thing to be said about the ASC Bill is that it bears all the hallmarks of a Lionel Bowen memorial. It is no secret that Mr Bowen does not propose to contest the next election. He is retiring from parliamentary politics after a very long innings. It is, therefore, not unusual, I guess, that Mr Bowen has for some time now been searching desperately for a legislative memorial to leave the nation. He has had several tries; the most recent and infamous was his absolutely disastrous attempt to force down the throat of the Australian electorate four dangerous referendum proposals last year. The people of Australia showed unequivocally what they thought of that idea-they rejected all four referendums by the greatest margin in Australia's history. The overturn of the highly regarded and respected cooperative scheme and its replacement with a centralised, bureaucratised, Canberra dominated, so-called national scheme is Mr Bowen's latest attempt to build a temple to his political career. No matter what the cost, no matter what the disruption, no matter what the uncertainty, no matter what the damaging effects to the Australian economy, Mr Bowen relentlessly pushes ahead to construct his temple. I believe he must not be permitted to do so, because for Australia Mr Bowen's temple would be a temple of doom built on shifting sands.

talk.start.para: —We have the war crimes one, too.

—Yes, we have the war crimes legislation, as my colleague pointed out. So desperate was Mr Bowen to have his temple that he permitted little or no genuine meaningful consultation to occur before introducing the legislation into the House of Representatives 11 months ago. True, he set up a steering committee and, subsequently, a consultative group to assist him in developing his proposals. However, the steering committee was not sufficiently broadly based, and the consultative group did little by way of consultation. The full consultative group met only once and achieved little except an agreement to subdivide into four more manageable groups, only one of which, the legal subcommittee, could be described as having been active. No indication was given that it had made any genuine attempt to canvass issues outside its own professional circle, let alone explore the views in the smaller States. State governments had little involvement in the consultative process. The Victorian Government, for example, told us that it did not see the Bills until after they had been introduced into this Parliament. It seems the same was the case with the other States. I also find it extraordinary that the existing corporate watchdog, the highly regarded NCSC, was not formally consulted until two months after the legislation had been introduced into the House of Representatives. It very quickly became apparent to us as we took evidence that there was a very high level of concern and unease about the inadequacy of the consultation process.

speech.para: A matter of similar grave concern-all geared to Mr Bowen's grandiose wish for a temple in which to house his political epitaph-was the totally unrealistic timeframe for the Joint Select Committee's report. Although the Committee was established by resolution of both Houses on 17 October last, the practical situation was that the Committee could not hold its first public hearings before 30 January. It received some 58 submissions totalling 1,000 pages. On top of that, it took evidence at public hearings which filled another 1,500 pages. Yet it was supposed to complete its report in time to present it to the Senate on 28 February. The Senate granted an extension of time until today, 13 April. But this was still a completely unrealistic deadline if the report were to be as high quality as such an important subject demands. As is said in the dissenting report on page 198, and I quote:

. . . the attitude of the Federal Government in relation to these bills seems to have been that a uniform national scheme must be fully implemented as soon as possible, irrespective of the validity of any objections. Such was the tightness of the deadlines faced by the Committee that it was necessary for the Secretariat to commence drafting the report on the basis of written submissions, before having heard the relevant oral evidence.

One outcome of . . . this unreasonably short period of time was that the Committee was unable to give proper consideration to a number of important issues. These included the report of the investigation into Rothwells and the transcript of the NCSC hearing into the Bell Bond SGIC matter. Both of these would have thrown considerable light on the practical operations of corporate regulation in Australia. Furthermore, the shortness of time meant that the Committee was unable to deal with a number of issues raised in the submissions or to ensure the technical adequacy of some of the recommendations.

The Committee was also unable to deal, other than in the most perfunctory manner, with such major subjects as the regulation of insider trading or the shield of the crown. So great has been the time pressure that printed copies are not yet available for all senators and members-a fact for which I apologise on behalf of the Committee. Copies will be available later today. The Government has steadfastly refused to admit that there are serious doubts about whether its package has constitutional validity. It has relied greatly on a positive advising by Sir Maurice Byers. The Government has sought no private opinions on the matter. The Committee received a good deal of evidence which, at the very least, raises serious doubts about the constitutional backing to the package. These are contained in the dissenting report. They include the unanimous view of the States' Solicitors-General, the Law Institute of Victoria, and many reputable lawyers and commentators. At the very least, it is quite certain that there would be High Court challenges to the legislation, and that the challenge process would be lengthy. The resultant uncertainty in the companies and securities industries during this process would be destabilising and damaging. The loss of business confidence would be severe.

The Government and other advocates of the centralised approach appear to rely on three main arguments for support. These are, firstly, that if Australia is to compete effectively in the international arena, a centralised national scheme for companies and securities law is necessary; secondly, that the existing cooperative arrangements diffuse ministerial responsibility and reduce accountability to parliament; and, thirdly, that the cooperative arrangements cause administrative inefficiencies and duplications and general inefficiency. The dissenting report deals with each of these arguments at some length. I believe that each of them is seriously flawed. The first argument-that Australia needs a centralised ASC because of the increasing globalisation of financial markets-whilst superficially appealing, can be demonstrated on closer examination to be nothing more than a straw man. Indeed, if one looks at the operation of Australian companies overseas and the general operations of our financial and securities markets under the existing arrangements, there is no evidence at all to suggest that we are running into any difficulties because of the lack of a more centralised scheme.

The argument about diffusion of power can be put both ways. The Committee received very little substantive evidence to indicate that this has in reality been a major problem. Indeed, there are powerful arguments to the contrary. As the dissenting report points out, the dispersal of power is by no means unhealthy. On the contrary, it constitutes a valuable and necessary safeguard to protect the integrity and independence of the regulatory authority. The following statement is made on page 204 of the dissenting report:

The spread of responsibility amongst State Attorneys-General of different political persuasions makes it infinitely harder to subvert or deflect the corporate watchdog and the, at times, anguished criticism of the NCSC by certain affected persons is eloquent testimony to its independence and effectiveness. A cogent example of the potential for political considerations to influence the conduct of corporate regulation occurred in the wake of the provisional liquidation of Rothwells.

Despite having the power to order a special investigation, the Attorney-General, Mr Bowen, declined to do so in the lead up to the Western Australian election. His suggestion that it was a matter for the States was disingenuous and was directly at odds with the thrust of the present legislation. Indeed, the decision by the NCSC not to disclose the name of Mr Laurie Connell in the wake of the October crash seemed to have been taken as a result of pressure being brought to bear by a person, whom Mr Bosch described as having ``considerable political connections.''
These examples highlight the necessity to avoid placing sole discretion in the hands of any politician.

On the third argument, namely, the duplication and resulting inefficiency alleged of the existing scheme, it seems clear from the evidence we received that the new scheme would not change to any marked extent the present administrative arrangements which, in any event, have generally been considered to work effectively.

There is a great deal more that needs to be said about the report and the Bills to which it relates. That discussion and debate will occur when we consider the Bills in a few weeks time. I urge the Government to take very serious note of the recommendations in this report, both in the main report and in the dissenting report. Setting aside for the moment the type of scheme to be adopted, there are many good recommendations in the report for improvements to the Corporations Bill.

So far as the particular scheme to be adopted is concerned, I want to emphasise in the strongest possible terms the following views outlined in the dissenting report: that the proposal to abolish the cooperative scheme and replace it with a centralised scheme with an Australian securities commission as the linchpin should be rejected; that the existing cooperative scheme has served, and continues to serve, Australia well; and that the NCSC is widely respected and regarded as an effective regulatory agency. The dissenting report also found that, to work, the ASC proposal of the Government needs the cooperation of the States, yet every State is bitterly opposed to it. Further, the dissenting report points out that the proposal would centralise power in the hands of one Minister, and the Federal Attorney-General, and one government, the Federal government, and would thereby make the regulation of Australia's highly sensitive and vitally important companies and securities law dangerously subject to political influence and interference. It also points out that the Government's proposals will face extensive High Court challenge, during which lengthy period the companies and securities industries would be subject to great uncertainty and the undermining of investor confidence at a time when it is essential that that confidence be strengthened.

The dissenting report put the view that the existing cooperative scheme can and should be improved, and my coalition colleagues and I fully support changes to achieve this. However, it found that no compelling case had been produced to support the need for the quite fundamental structural changes to the regulatory framework that are contained in the ASC Bill. On the contrary, there are strong arguments against such fundamental change.

I commend the Joint Select Committee's report to all senators and members, to the business community and to the financial media. It is an important report which I hope will be widely read and carefully considered.

speech.speaker: McMullan Sen R.F.

talk.start.para: —I must say initially that I am somewhat surprised that we are having such an extensive debate today on the report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation. It was not my understanding that this was to be the case. I share Senator Short's view that the main thrust of this document will most appropriately be debated during the second reading and committee stages of the legislation. Nevertheless, I am pleased to have the opportunity to join in the debate on the motion to take note of the report because I also share with Senator Short the view that it is an important report. I disagree with him, of course, about some of the conclusions he has brought to our attention. But the report is important and the Committee has engaged in a very worthwhile process.

speech.para: I also want to join with Senator Short in congratulating the Chairman of the Committee, Ron Edwards, the honourable member for Stirling, who did an outstanding job in very difficult circumstances, in the public role he played in representing the Committee, in chairing the public and private proceedings, and in bringing the report to its final formulation. I also join in congratulating the staff and the advisers to the Committee, in particular Andrew Sneddon and Mark Dickens, who both made contributions without which it would have been impossible to produce a report. I have noticed one or two errors in those parts of the report that I have had a chance to read. However, I am advised that a corrigendum will be produced shortly to correct those matters. Overwhelmingly, given the time that was available, the report was an outstanding production.

As we are to have a considerable second reading debate and, I am sure, a very extensive committee debate on this legislation, I thought in speaking to the report I would concentrate on questions of underlying principles. As one of the members of the Committee who, not being a lawyer, had to do more fundamental research than some of my colleagues, I approached this matter from an outcomes point of view. I will make some comments about secondary matters in a moment, but the principal matter we are pursuing is the question of economic efficiency. It is about micro-economic reform throughout Australia; it is about establishing a corporate fund raising regime and an administration of corporate law which will be appropriate for the present and be ready for the demands of the remainder of the twentieth century and into the twenty-first century. That is the reason why we are at this stage moving to a unified national system.

I believe that the cooperative scheme was a substantial improvement when it was introduced. It did enhance significantly the proper administration of corporate law in Australia and the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) has in many ways played an outstanding role. But time is passing. We are moving into a more international economic and business environment and the era of 24-hour trading is with us. The major corporations in Australia, the corporations that trade internationally, support this initiative for that reason. They also support it, quite correctly in my view, because it simplifies the conduct of business on a national scale and guarantees uniformity and consistency of administration from State to State. It should also provide the opportunity, as is reflected in the majority report, for prompt and consistent rulings. I will not dwell on that as it is covered in the report. There is also the important question of the principle of parliamentary accountability, which was challenged by the minority. I understand the argument, but I do agree with it. It is only the establishment of parliamentary accountability which will create the framework for effective continuing parliamentary scrutiny. The report recommends the establishment of a joint standing committee to monitor this new legislation and the operation of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). Such a joint standing committee could not possibly be effective under the cooperative scheme because the NCSC would not be accountable to the Federal Parliament. It could not operate.

The time has come-in fact I think it is long past-to mark the end of the lowest common denominator approach to corporate regulation. It is that which killed off the compromise proposal, which was an interesting proposal emanating from the Attorneys-General of Victoria and South Australia. It had substantial merit, but the inherent flaw in the cooperative scheme, that it depends upon the cooperation of the weakest link, was exhibited in the reaction to that proposal. It was killed off and therefore did not warrant any further consideration. That lowest common denominator approach, and the problems associated with it, were clearly exhibited in the extremely unsatisfactory evidence given to the Committee by the New South Wales Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Peacocke. It was a contribution that smacked of the bad old days of the Bjelke-Petersen regime in the early 1970s. It was uncooperative, ill-formed and unsatisfactory. I think that reflects why the cooperative scheme cannot operate in the future in the way in which its advocates might wish.

The minority, in its dissenting report, said two things that are important at this stage-one with which I agree and which Senator Short referred to in his comments, and one with which I disagree. The first, which is very important, is that the Committee was unanimous in most areas of its recommendations about the way in which corporations should be regulated, whether by a national scheme or a cooperative scheme. Equally interesting in that area is that the dissent crossed party lines quite substantially. Three of the five Labor members, one of the Liberal members and an Australian Democrat voted differently to the majority-that majority being a majority on the casting vote of the Chairman. I will not bore the Senate with the detail of that. It is clearly outlined in the report and it would more appropriately be debated in the committee stage. My point is that that bipartisan, or multipartisan, approach to the detail, while reflecting well on the Committee-which is not a point of any significance-is important in terms of the benefit that can be gained from an analysis of the report.

But that point in the report of the Committee with which I do not agree reflects the problem with the cooperative scheme. Page 216 of the report states that the Bill reflects changes which are required in corporations law. I agree with that. It states also that the cooperative scheme can be rectified without difficulty to achieve this objective. That is where we part company. Its sensible assessment that those changes need to be made, which reflects the majority report with which I concur, falls down at the implementation stage because I do not believe the cooperative scheme either can or will achieve those objectives.

The Committee strayed into the constitutional area. It was outside our terms of reference, and I do not intend to stray into it in making my comments, other than to say that I think the transitional arrangements on which the Committee makes recommendations are important. A prompt resolution of the major constitutional questions, which is guaranteed by the Attorney-General, is also important, and I look forward to that. I am confident about the outcome but that, of course, is a matter for the High Court of Australia to decide.

The Committee in its approach-and I as a member of it-had to balance a number of competing demands. One was the balance between the effective policing of the marketplace and the civil liberties of the participants in the marketplace. I pay tribute to my colleague Senator Cooney for his consistent advocacy of the civil liberties of almost everybody, which he undertook at great length and with great expertise. This is the area in which the dissent finally emerged. It is a difficult balance, although it is not a unique balance, to achieve. It is not dissimilar to that which has to be dealt with in the area of the National Crime Authority and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. For that reason we have parliamentary committee scrutiny of those two bodies. Therefore it is appropriate that a committee should continue to scrutinise this proposal.

But here we have a third element of the balance. We have the question of effective policing of civil liberties and of market efficiency. It is a difficult balance to achieve but I think it is a balance which the report strikes and which the Bill will strike if it reflects the recommendations in the report. For example, recommendation 6 on page xvi of the summary of recommendations refers to the need to maintain effective day to day market surveillance. The report also mentions empowering the ASC to proceed for recovery of profits in a number of areas particularly, for example, insider trading. The Committee, significantly, recommends enhanced pre-vetting of prospectuses, a view which I supported and which was ultimately unanimously supported.

Readers of the report will also note that in a bipartisan way Senator Alston and I disagreed with the rest of the Committee about the question of pre-vetting of part A statements in takeovers. Once again, that is a matter that can be discussed at greater length later. My view is that that is fundamentally another area of secondary trading. We have made appropriate unanimous recommendations for the regulation of secondary trading on the market, and I believe those will also adequately cover the circumstances in regard to takeovers. It is distinctly differently from the prospectus situation, where the relative strength of the players in the market is so disproportionately different. That is the case for continuing regulation of corporations law in the way that is proposed in the report, which is somewhat more regulatory in its tone than some elements of the Bill, although it is slightly less so than the current system in the main. But it is a market that requires regulation because of the disproportionately different resources available to, and strength of, the participants in the marketplace. It is a market in which there are an enormous number of very wealthy players and a lower number of smaller players. In this instance the smaller players are not those people who were mentioned in last night's economic statement, the poorest of the poor. There are not-or there should not be-too many recipients of the family allowance supplement participating in the stock exchange.

The survey done by the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges, as it then was, of Australian share ownership in 1986 showed that 17 per cent of share owners listed their occupation as executive and professional. Grouped in with those who were either retired from that category, or probably linked to it by family circumstances, is a group of 35 to 40 per cent of share owners, whereas only 5.5 per cent are identified as blue collar workers. Of course it is vastly different from the distribution of those occupational groupings in the work force as a whole. The interests of most of those people at the lower end of the market, the employees, who are represented to some extent in the share market through their superannuation schemes, are taken care of by rather big players in the marketplace, the superannuation companies. Therefore, some of their interests do not necessarily have to be protected in that way. The National Mutual Life Association of Australia Ltd and the Australian Mutual Provident Society are certainly big enough to take care of themselves. But evidence will show the continuing reference to the little old grandmother who participates in the market. Whether that is ageist and sexist is beside the point for the moment. There are people who are not informed, professional and powerful figures who purchase shares on the stock exchange. They are entitled to be treated fairly. They are entitled to be well informed. They are entitled to have as equal a chance as we can give them to participate on a footing comparable with the more powerful players. I do not want to say any more about the report than that by way of preliminary remarks. There are some things I want to say in the second reading debate and the committee stage.

The report does contain-I say this by way of conclusion-some other clarifications, some of them quite minor and some more substantial, but all of them unanimous, of matters raised by witnesses. The legislation is enormous and complex. I do not pretend to have become an instant expert because I have been on the Committee for two or three months, but it has been a very steep learning curve. The conclusions one should draw from reading this report are that the legislation should proceed. The legislation should be, and, if the recommendations in the report are adopted, will be, substantially enhanced by the report. There is a need for continuing monitoring, which should be done by the Joint Parliamentary Committee. It should assist in ensuring the balance of those competing demands of efficiency, equity and civil liberties in a way that would not be possible in the cooperative scheme. I am happy to join in the discussion on the motion and I commend the report to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the report from the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, which was set up following my motion, as set out in the opening pages of this report. When I first approached the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) with the suggestion that there ought to be a committee of inquiry into this subject, he readily accepted that view, and for much the same reason that I put to him-that is, that since these Bills are the largest group of Bills ever to be introduced into the Federal Parliament since Federation, it would be odd if they went through both Houses without a committee inquiry. That Committee has now met. It has met under a very tight timetable. However, I do not agree with the remarks made by the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, Senator Short, that a vastly extended exercise would necessarily have done anything other than produce more amendments to particular items. I think what we have done is suggested not only the immediate amendments that need to be undertaken-with the unanimous agreement of all members of the Committee-but also a method by which those subsequent items may be able to be taken up, that is, by the continuation of a joint committee of members of parliament to be known as the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities.

speech.para: The Committee worked extremely well. In fact, I found it to be a committee where one was able to listen to expertise and views from members of all political parties and take them on the basis of argument and expertise and not on the basis of which political party people belonged to. Fairly obviously, that particular atmosphere has departed already now that the report has been tabled. I wish to refer to that because I think it was a most constructive exercise. That is not to say that the Liberal and National Party members of our Committee departed from the view that they did not believe that these Bills should proceed. But they were able to suspend that on a conditional exercise: if they were to proceed, whether they could be made better. Hence the report was able to be signed by every member of the Committee no matter which party they came from-under that rubric, that if the Bills are to proceed, then these are the recommended changes. I believe that the Government certainly has to look very closely at these recommendations. I would go so far as to say that I believe the Government ought to take on board every one of these recommendations, that it would be advised to do so and in doing that the Bills will be far better and will be the best we are able to achieve at this stage in terms of proceeding.

There was another method we used in the Committee which I originally suggested to the Chairman of the Committee and which the Committee itself was happy to take up-that is, that we should seek to have attached to our Committee a number of experts who would travel with us, who would sit in on the hearings and who would then be able to make comments from their various points of expertise. These people-Brian O'Callaghan from the Attorney-General's Department, Mark Dickens from the National Companies and Securities Commission, and Michael Heffernan from the Australian Stock Exchange-performed an extremely valuable task. I would certainly recommend to the Senate that in terms of all of its committees, it look at this particular innovation and talk to the members of the Committee as to how that worked to see whether that additional aspect might aid in other technical matters before various committees. The procedure we had was that those three people from various areas, but with deep expertise and professionalism, were able to comment immediately to us on witnesses' answers and submissions. At the end of each day we were then able to undertake a much more in-depth debate than we would otherwise have been able to do. The alternative method would have been for us to then leave the Committee room and seek the type of input from experts that we were able to gain immediately and on the submissions made.

I also take some point with the other comment made by Senator Short when he got into some fairly high-blown rhetoric with regard to the temple of doom. I must admit that I have never seen the Deputy Prime Minister very much as an Indiana Jones figure. I doubt whether he has ever seen himself in that light. Whether this particular Bill is seen by Senator Short as building some type of temple to the political career of Lionel Bowen is really quite beside the point. The fact of the matter-it is substantiated in the evidence-is that all of the major companies and the members of the Business Council of Australia are in support of this scheme. The vast bulk of companies in Australia, the overwhelming majority, are in support of this scheme as is evident by the support given by the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia in evidence. Those two facts-the fact that the major companies are in support of this scheme and that the vast majority of companies support it-would suggest that what is going on here is a very interesting exercise. They are looking at this in a similar way to the way my Party has looked at this particular piece of legislation-that is, that this particular legislation is not for the past; it is not really for the present. I think the point is that the cooperative scheme could limp along in the present. This particular piece of legislation, quite frankly, is for the future of Australian business.

That is a totally different perspective. It is one that is not met in the minority report. This legislation is for the future of Australian business. I would suggest that if this legislation fails as a result, for example, of an election and a change of government which would not proceed with the legislation, then at some time in the future, probably within a 10- to 15-year time frame, the pressure for a similar scheme to this will be almost irresistible.

That can be looked at by merely looking at the trends in Australian business and in our trade. We have to think as a nation, as a country. We will survive only by thinking in that way-a nation that is interested in and committed to trade in the international arena. In doing that-in the same way as yesterday the Senate passed a Bill in regard to international arbitration-we need not just to have regard to the brawls that take place in the day to day business of political parties in this place, but to appreciate that the economic future of this country depends on the legislative regime that we put in place for our companies. We will be long gone, and only names appearing in Hansard, when the real benefits of this legislation will be seen.

talk.start.para: —We will be historic figures.

—One hopes that one will but, like most people in the past, one tends to disappear in the footnotes of history. I suppose if one can range through history as a footnote it is something. This legislation will stay there and will be a hallmark to the fact that we were able to look ahead. I urge honourable senators to examine this legislation in that vein. Although it is true that we could get by today and tomorrow on the cooperative scheme-and there is no doubt about that-we will not be able to do that in the foreseeable future. It is far better to take the opportunity now to make these changes so that we can put in place the type of legislative regime that will be necessary.

speech.para: The final point I wish to make before closing is that I hope that the Senate and the House of Representatives adopt the recommendation in regard to a joint committee on corporations and securities. The reason I say this-which probably will not come as much of a surprise to many people in this chamber-is that I have an abiding interest in the future of parliamentary democracy. I believe that we need to give a reason for the continued existence of parliament, not just simply because of the fact that it was here yesterday, or because of King Charles or somebody else. The reason that parliaments should continue is that we are relevant to the day to day lives of the people of Australia. To do that we have to stay with the times.

This House first came into session in 1901, and what else has continued since that time in its original form? There is hardly anything else. In other words, we have an obligation not just simply to preach to everybody else that they have to remain with the times, but parliamentarians have to keep up with the times also. One way in which this chamber pre-eminently in this Parliament has chosen to do that is through its committees. I believe that that has a twofold effect, particularly as to this recommendation. The first is that it will provide access to a group from all parties for business. Where business feels that this legislation is pinching or needs to be changed, or where business has a problem with some decision on which it needs to express its view; business will be able to talk to a committee of all political parties. It will not just talk to bureaucrats or to the Government, but also to a committee of all political parties.

The second aspect-this is where the benefit flows to us-is that it will require a number of members of both Houses to be continuously involved in an ongoing learning way with operations of corporation securities in this country. I believe that would be the marked benefit of the debates in this chamber. I believe that we should look at that as an exercise not only for the corporations but also for our own benefit and for the benefit of parliamentary democracy.

In recommending the report of the Committee, may I delineate basically what we have. We have a fundamental dissent expressed by the minority report with the concept that has already been aired; it has not changed. Indeed, it would be remarkable, in terms of the evidence presented to us, if it had changed. There is a fundamental difference, it continues, and it is expressed by members of the conservative parties on the Committee in that minority report. That aside, the Committee was unanimous on every point except one. Once one puts aside the fundamental political differences, the members of the Committee was in agreement on every point except one. When one turns to the report to look at where that disagreement occurs, one finds a dissenting report signed by Senator Alston, Senator Cooney, Senator Macklin, Senator McMullan and Mr Kerr. In other words, on only one point was there any disagreement. That is evidence of how well the members of the Committee worked together, how well we were able to listen to one another's arguments. We were very lucky to have the valuable input of a number of members on that Committee who were lawyers and who had expertise in this area. I found their input personally invaluable.

The Committee worked in a way that is characteristic of Senate committees in working for the betterment of legislation. We will return to our political debates now, but I do not think any of us who have gone through this exercise could in any shape or form believe that it was useless. I think that we are all committed to the propositions contained in the report. We have put our recommendations which-when accepted rather than if-will vastly improve the legislation. We will then be left with that still fundamental dissent as to whether we should proceed, but that is still a matter for politics. I believe that if we were having this debate in 15 years' time or possibly even in five or six years' time, this argument would be put to us by a conservative government urging this scheme. I urge all honourable senators to read the report because it will enlighten them on many issues. It was an experience for me for which I am very thankful. I hope that our work will assist the people of Australia, particularly those in business, well into the future.

speech.speaker: Alston Sen R.K.R.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to address the Senate on what is undoubtedly one of the most significant reports tabled in the Parliament. I regard it as a great privilege to have served on the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation. Indeed, I congratulate Senator Macklin in particular for persuading the Government that this matter should be referred to a parliamentary committee. As a result of that exercise we have had perhaps the most intelligent, yet technical, discussion of issues relating to administration of company law that has ever taken place in this Parliament. I commend all my colleagues on the Committee, in particular its Deputy Chairman, Senator Short. It is fair to say that almost all members of the Committee-and I do not include Senator Cooney in the exceptions-attended every meeting and played a very constructive role. I thought that Senator Cooney did his best and in his attempts to provoke me and others he was singularly unsuccessful. In retailing his experience of life at the Victorian Bar, we were all vastly entertained. There were even times when I suspect that he might have done a bit of company law in an earlier life. Overall, we did address the issue seriously and sensibly. I think, as other speakers have said, there was a large measure of agreement on the need for improvements in the area dealt with by the Corporations Bill. It is really in the area of the concept of the Australian National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC), the need for national legislation to replace the current cooperative scheme, that I think the parties diverge.

speech.para: It is interesting to reflect on the views of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, as it then was. I think many of the broad-brush statements contained in that report commended themselves to a number of those who made submissions. They did not really get down to the detail that our Committee certainly did. I found that a fascinating exercise. Perhaps I could just take one example. I know Senator Macklin has been driven by the desire for Australia to become more competitive, to find its place in the international arena, to ensure that we are not hampered by any outmoded regulations. I think that is a perfectly commendable point of view. Certainly it was a view put to us by players such as the Business Council of Australia. But when I examined that particular argument in favour of a national scheme and all of the accompanying rhetoric about the need to replace outmoded schemes by approaches that would take us into the twenty-first century, it became apparent to me that really there was no evidence at all that would demonstrate that companies were presently hampered in their international operations by the scheme under which we operate. After all, only a very small proportion of companies operate in the international arena, and none of those has ever suggested that their entrepreneurial endeavours have been hindered to any extent by having to operate under a ministerial council and a cooperative scheme.

When one looks at some of the assertions made on behalf of the Business Council, such things as the need for a national computer base and the ability to assess quickly and easily corporate records throughout the country, it becomes apparent that these were shibboleths that have been around for many years and which have been overtaken by events. The fact is that there will be a national corporate data base in the very near future and people will have that sort of instant access to which they are undoubtedly entitled. So I found that argument singularly unpersuasive. It is certainly one of those slogans that were bandied around, but I think the commentators and others made it fairly clear that, once you got beneath the surface, there was really no evidence to suggest that companies were being restricted. There are a number of leading Australian companies that are major players on the international scene that have to cope with many vagaries, including fluctuating prices, exchange rates, language and cultural barriers and adequate access to capital investment resources, but none of them ever suggest that the method of regulating company law in Australia has somehow limited their opportunities. I found that one argument that was really a red herring.

The second argument in favour of a national scheme was that somehow the ability of this Parliament to influence the shape of regulation was limited to the point where we were irrelevant. Those who place great store on the sovereignty of the Parliament felt somehow insulted that we were not in there making all the changes. The reality is, as I think was clearly demonstrated to us, that the Federal Parliament does have the ability to amend legislation, to adopt or reject recommendations of the Ministerial Council. It is then a matter of whether the States are prepared to accept those changes. But I think there is little doubt that the Federal Government is legally free to reject or amend legislation. If that is the case, one wonders what the fuss is about. Again I was struck by the conspicuous lack of examples of any actual or proposed changes that either the Commonwealth or the States have proposed which have proved unacceptable to the other. I think one can say that, far from it being undesirable that there has not been what is described as direct accountability to the Parliament, there is a very good and valid reason why the cooperative scheme has proved very worthwhile: it minimises the opportunity for political influence. In many ways I think this goes to the heart of the matter.

Since 1979 company law in Australia has been administered within a framework of a Federal-State cooperative scheme presided over by the Attorneys-General of the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. Under that regime the National Companies and Securities Commission has been Australia's national corporate watchdog. Over the past decade the Commission has established a reputation as a vigorous and determined all-rounder. Its activities have covered not only technical areas such as accounting standards and regulations but also crucial areas such as investor protection and law enforcement. Its most visible and contentious activities have centred on its efforts to ensure a level playing field for both investors and companies. This has involved continuous market surveillance, being constantly on the look-out for market manipulation, especially in the area of takeovers. Amongst its most important powers has been the ability to inquire into allegations of unacceptable conduct and to obtain court orders for forfeiture of shares and restraint on market activities. It has issued a steady stream of press releases designed to keep the public and the market informed on its attitude to corporate behaviour. It has done all that despite being provided by the Federal Government with a niggardly shoestring budget of the order of $6m.

I do not share the criticism that I know Senator Cooney has voiced on occasions of the way in which Mr Bosch and his colleagues have taken a media-oriented approach to the activities of the regulator. I think they have been in part driven by the fact that they cannot afford to embark on the more traditional approaches, which often involve long and costly litigation. I take the view that there is nothing more salutary than the spotlight of media attention to discourage those who might otherwise be fringe operators from engaging in activities which we would regard as unacceptable conduct.

Because of the shortness of time and the lack of opportunity for the Committee to consider very important reports, one being the report into the Rothwells Ltd matter, the other the Bell-Bond-State Government Insurance Commission takeover deal, we were not provided with the opportunity to analyse the effectiveness of the NCSC in the way that I would have liked. I regard it as unfortunate that in that particular instance the NCSC felt constrained to arrive at a commercial settlement, which meant that it did not proceed to make a definite finding of unacceptable conduct. I think Mr Alan Bond should be very grateful that the NCSC found itself in that position. In part that was contributed to by the defence of the shield of the Crown, which I regard as quite outmoded. I think it has allowed a number of government instrumentalities to operate effectively outside the law so that it has become a matter of discretion whether they comply with vital legislative requirements such as the takeovers code.

It is simply not acceptable, in my view, that old-fashioned notions of sovereignty of the Crown should operate to deny investors and the wider community knowledge of the commercial activities of governments in the marketplace, in the same way that they are entitled as of right to knowledge of the activities of private corporations. Because of that continuing availability of the shield of the Crown argument, commercial settlements have been arrived at when they would not otherwise have been quite so compelling. Certainly I think the Bond Corporation was one of those against whom an unacceptable declaration ought to have been made, on the evidence. If that had been the case, I think there might have been some other harsher views taken of the activities of the Western Australian State Government Insurance Commission.

If I could return to the central point, by and large the NCSC has got a number of runs on the board. I will not run through some of its achievements in recent years, but it certainly has forced a number of players to disgorge profits-in effect to put money into the poor box, as Senator Cooney would appreciate-to the tune of $1m as far as the IEL Property Trust was concerned. Even the Bond group was required to pay an extra $580m to minority shareholders in the Bell Group. I think the Commission's achievements in respect of forcing FAI Insurances to reverse its sale of a stake in Cumberland Credit Corporation, forcing Alexander Laing and Cruickshank to sell a disputed parcel of Humes Ltd shares, are all very good and recent examples of the effectiveness of the NCSC. It has been able to do that against a background of niggardliness on the part of both Federal and State governments. It is quite clear that the Federal Government could have provided resources if it had chosen to, but simply has not. That is a very regrettable state of affairs. Clearly it has limited the Commission's options. It is a disincentive to pursue litigation, which is often a necessary weapon to keep the main players in line.

Another thing I regard as regrettable is a very important takeover which has gone largely unnoticed. I refer to the great victory by the public sector unions in ensuring that all staff of the regulator will come within the Public Service Act. At the moment, the NCSC is not constrained by Public Service requirements. It is able to employ its own staff. Subject to the availability of funds, it is not really required to operate under a pricing cap either. What will happen now is that everyone employed by the regulator will have to be a public servant, a career bureaucrat, subject to all the limits imposed by award restrictions. If that is the case, then it will be a much less attractive place for aspiring corporate lawyers to go. Those often fired with enthusiasm about the role that can be played by an honest and effective regulator and who are not particularly concerned about wages will be very concerned about the dead hand of bureaucracy. If this is going to be a sheltered workshop for public servants, then that is a very unfortunate and unhealthy development. It is to the Government's great shame that it has capitulated to those pressures. It was not necessary and, in many ways, it has become just an excuse for its failure to provide the necessary funding.

I am also concerned that a national scheme might provide the Australian Democrats with an opportunity to influence the course of corporate law in this country. I regard that as a fairly frightening prospect for the commercial community. Senator Macklin, who has been a voice of relative rationality in this debate, is shortly to depart this place. What we are likely to be left with is a clutch of anti-business prejudices, which are constantly trotted out in this place by popularists and demagogues like Senator Haines. They bitterly oppose any notion of takeovers, resent companies offsetting borrowings for takeovers against income and, indeed, distrust any foreign investment in this country. Companies rank high in their demonology. That is very unfortunate if the Democrats have the balance of power in deciding the shape of company law in this country.

That is a separate issue in one sense; the major issue is the unfortunate capacity for influence and the level of influence that will be available to some of the major corporate advisers and players, in particular the Sydney Mafia, from whom I exclude Mr John Green. I certainly regard it as an unhealthy development if we find the NCSC, which is beholden to a ministerial council composed of politicians of various persuasions, replaced by a single avenue of approach. The Attorney-General's Department is very keen to get its hands into the area, and we have an Attorney-General who already has a prior conviction for political interference, or non-interference, in his conscious decision not to conduct an inquiry into the affairs of Rothwells prior to the Western Australian election. Given the very unsatisfactory evidence presented to the Committee in Sydney particularly by Mr Vrisakis, who put forward what I regarded as a self-serving, fulsome and dishonest statement about consultation, one can only have a great level of concern about the quite obvious lack of consultation and real awareness on the part of other than a very small clique. If that is the case, it augurs badly. It means that that situation is likely to be aggravated by a system that will allow people a fast track to Canberra to influence decisions, most of which will never see the light of day unless they are actually decisions not to prosecute. But, in subtle ways, they will have a very deleterious effect on the way in which company law is shaped in this country.

This has been a very worthwhile exercise. The report has been very constructive in many aspects. On the fundamental need to replace the present cooperative scheme, I think that the majority has simply got it wrong. Those members have been seduced by simplistic notions. If they examine carefully the implications of that sort of a takeover, they will find that it will not serve the community well, will not be in anyone's best interests and, indeed, that there are very many ways in which the administration of the present scheme can be improved and made to operate quite satisfactorily. I hope that is the way that the Government and the Democrats will go, but I fear the worst.

speech.speaker: Cooney Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —The speeches so far have pointed out the importance of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation. I endorse those remarks. I also endorse the thanks that have been given to the staff who prepared the report. In particular I thank Andrew Sneddon, who has worked under extreme pressure and has presented a very good and comprehensive report and a report to be praised. No doubt there may be, as one reads through the report, the odd error, but that would be as a result of the pressure under which he has had to work. There has been some criticism of that pressure. On the other hand, this is legislation that is before the Parliament and has already been through the House of Representatives. It is important from the Government's point of view that it does proceed. I think a proper balance has been struck between the need to get a good and comprehensive report and the need to get the legislation through the chamber.

speech.para: Senator Alston praises the report in so far as it is a comprehensive analysis of the legislation. He, along with Senator Short and no doubt other members of his Party, criticises the report because he considers that this legislation should not be introduced at all and that the present cooperative scheme is the appropriate way to go, although it ought to be improved. That differs from the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which gave rise to this legislation. It was tabled in this Parliament on 28 April 1987 and was entitled The role of Parliament in relation to the national companies scheme. It is proper to refer to that because many of the issues that are now raised were then anticipated. It was recommended unanimously by the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee that the Commonwealth Parliament should enact comprehensive legislation covering the field currently regulated by the cooperative scheme. That Committee was made up of people of great force. The Chairman was Senator Nick Bolkus, who is now a Minister of the Crown. May I say that he is a man of outstanding experience in the law and has filled his position as a Minister with great consequence and great distinction. Senator Margaret Reynolds, who is also a Minister, was also on that Committee. Senator Michael Tate, who was the Chairman of that Committee until 25 February 1987, is now a Minister. The members of that Committee from the other side were Senator Robert Hill, Senator Richard Alston and Senator Chris Puplick. If the Opposition ever becomes the Government--

talk.start.para: —That is very remote.

—It is very remote, but if that happened, Senator Robert Hill, Senator Richard Alston and Senator Chris Puplick would fill the front bench; they would be Ministers. So this report was produced by people who are either now Ministers or will become Ministers, presupposing the Opposition gets into government. The only other name there was mine. I doubt that I will make the front bench as a member of either this Party or the other one.
—You never know.

—Yes, one never knows. It is said that there is no need for a Commonwealth scheme. The reality is that that report was a unanimous one made by those very outstanding people. They unanimously recommended that the Commonwealth have a comprehensive scheme. Senator Alston said that there was no evidence that that should be the situation. In paragraph 5.1 of this report it is pointed out that:

speech.para: Mr Halstead, a committee member of the Business Council of Australia and one of the Council's representatives at the Committee's public hearings, summarised the Council's submission as being `that the Commonwealth Government should make a bid for the whole field'.
The report points out that the Australian Merchant Bankers Association also appears to have come to this view. Paragraph 5.2 of the report states:

. . . Mr Bill Beerworth, a member of the executive committee of the Australian Merchant Bankers Association, commented that he had `always had doubts about the co-operative scheme' and that the Association `is on record as preferring national legislation in this area'.
Paragraph 5.3 of the report states:
The Company Directors Association characterised this as the `next step' in a natural progression. According to the Chief Executive of the Confederation of Australian Industry, Mr Darryl George:
The present system of State and Federal cooperation on company regulation has now proven its limitations and should be abolished.
Significantly, paragraph 3.52 of the report of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs states:
In a statement to the Victorian Legislative Council in 1985, the Victorian Attorney-General, the Hon. J. H. Kennan, MLC-
an outstanding legal mind-

described the co-operative companies and securities scheme as `a unique constitutional creature'. His successor as Chairman of the Ministerial Council, the Hon. T. W. Sheahan, has taken a negative view of the scheme. He described it as a `hybrid institution' which `imposes severe limitations on developing of necessary policies.

That man was Chairman of the Ministerial Council at that time. He said that the scheme was not working well and that we should move to a national scheme run through the Parliament of Australia. That is consistent with the fact that the Australian Stock Exchange has become a national body and that there is international trade in securities. This demands more and more that there be a single body to regulate the exchange of securities in various countries. So, a national scheme has been asked for and given by this Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). This Attorney is to be praised for his moves in that area.

Time is short and we want to finish as soon as we can. There is one other point. There was a split in the Committee-five all-with the majority being formed by the casting vote of the Chairman, Mr Ron Edwards, who chaired the Committee with great distinction. That split in the Committee took place over the role of the proposed Australian Securities Commission and the panel. It is a fundamental concept in the legislation that there be a separation of functions. There are those which are, according to the minority report of five, to be performed by the Australian Securities Commission, which is an investigative body that collects intelligence, establishes evidence and then produces it. That function is distinct from an adjudicative one, from one where judgments are to be made. The scheme in the legislation presently before us proposes that that adjudicative function be performed by a panel. It is my strong belief that that is how it should remain. As I understood it, that is what the industry wanted. The panel will include people from the industry who can be chosen from a wide pool. It is proper that that is where the decision as to whether there has been unacceptable conduct is made.

It is undesirable in any institution in a democratic society that people who investigate and collect intelligence also be allowed to judge an issue on the basis of the material that they gather. With great respect to the majority-a majority because of the casting vote of the Chairman-I am unable to accept that, even in an industry where it is suggested, often times with insufficient evidence, that there is a need for severe control, that control should be so severe as to run those two functions together. That sort of thing is the basis for the addendum I made on page 191 of the report about the tendency, not only in this sort of legislation but also in legislation generally, to allow citizens of this community to be punished, to have consequences delivered to them, by bodies which seem to run together functions that should not be run together. In other words, it is wrong for bodies that collect evidence or intelligence and investigate matters then to go ahead and make judgments upon that material. The legislation as it presently appears is the correct approach.

Senator Alston talked about Rothwells Ltd and Bell-Bond. He has been vigorous in his pursuit in bringing to the light of day what happened with those companies. That is correct. No doubt the opportunity will come his way. He has spoken of the shield of the Crown and the need to look at it. I agree entirely.
